subtitle: Sarah Arao Mantle of Hope- Thank You Video to the Y on Earth Community for GoFundMe Campaign Support
full_transcript:
[8.0s - 13.5s]: Welcome to the Writers' Community's Stewardship and Sustainability Podcast Series.

[14.2s - 21.1s]: Today we have the opportunity to visit with Farmer and Expert Educator Pat Frazier.

[21.4s - 21.8s]: Hi Pat.

[22.2s - 22.4s]: Hi.

[22.8s - 23.7s]: It's great to visit with you.

[23.7s - 24.1s]: Yeah.

[24.7s - 25.9s]: Good that you made it over.

[26.4s - 26.8s]: We did.

[26.9s - 29.4s]: We had a beautiful drive through the mountains to get here.

[29.4s - 29.9s]: Sweet.

[30.5s - 35.1s]: Pat Frazier has been a biodynamic farmer for over 20 years.

[35.6s - 42.0s]: She and her family have a small biodynamic homestead diversified farm and family dairy

[42.0s - 48.6s]: in western Colorado where all of the preparation herbs are grown and utilized in making the indigenous

[48.6s - 54.9s]: biodynamic preparations for her farm organism and western Colorado regional biodynamic

[54.9s - 55.6s]: group.

[56.6s - 61.8s]: Permaculture design is another of her passions and its marriage with biodynamics is included

[61.8s - 66.4s]: in her two-week residential permaculture certification in the summers.

[67.5s - 73.7s]: Pat is a passionate cultivator of the biodynamic agriculture movement speaking nationally and

[73.7s - 81.3s]: regionally at major biodynamic conferences and advising on three national organizations.

[82.0s - 86.7s]: She is the president of the Board of Directors of Josephine Porter Institute for Applied

[86.7s - 93.4s]: Biodynamics, the largest nonprofit distributor of biodynamic preparations in North America.

[93.8s - 98.9s]: And Pat, I have been looking forward to this conversation for quite a while now and I'm

[98.9s - 105.0s]: so thrilled we have the opportunity to share with our audience a direct conversation with

[105.0s - 110.4s]: you about biodynamics and permaculture and all of this amazing work we can be doing

[110.4s - 116.0s]: more of in our lives and in our homes regardless of our particular setting.

[116.7s - 118.8s]: So thanks for taking the time to visit with us.

[118.8s - 119.1s]: You're welcome.

[119.7s - 120.1s]: You're welcome.

[120.6s - 122.5s]: So we have a lot to talk about.

[122.8s - 125.8s]: What do you feel like would be a nice place to start?

[126.7s - 134.6s]: I think today the best place to start is one of the real main principles of either permaculture

[134.6s - 136.5s]: or biodynamics which is rhythm.

[138.0s - 141.8s]: So as you know we just passed the Fourth of July.

[142.7s - 151.7s]: Today is July 6th and we had a very auspicious day on the 3rd of July which was a day where

[151.7s - 158.8s]: the calendar indicated that in the cosmos there was an opposition happening.

[158.8s - 167.5s]: An opposition is where the moon is here, the earth is here and on the other side is a planet.

[168.5s - 176.9s]: And so the moon actually emphasizes and really brings forth all of the qualities and whatever

[176.9s - 179.6s]: planet is over here on the other side of the earth.

[180.4s - 186.5s]: And on July 3rd that happened to be moon opposed Saturn.

[187.5s - 196.4s]: Now Saturn when Rudolph Steiner spoke to us about biodynamics at that time Saturn was the furthest planet out.

[197.4s - 206.3s]: And so it was the planet where all evolution began with regards to what we now know as the earth evolution.

[207.5s - 214.1s]: And when it began evolving the only quality that Saturn had was warmth.

[215.1s - 219.7s]: It was the quality of warmth that generated all life.

[222.1s - 230.5s]: In biodynamics we have an association with certain plants on earth with certain planets.

[231.6s - 242.5s]: And those associations are what create some of the herbs and the fermented preparations that we use for fertility in biodynamics.

[244.1s - 254.5s]: In July usually at about this time in July one of the plants that associated with Saturn is in full bloom.

[255.8s - 267.3s]: And so on July 3rd not only was that plant in full bloom but that plant's associated planet Saturn was emphasized by the moon.

[268.3s - 277.0s]: So what we did on that day was a very rhythmic exercise where we harvested just the flowers of the plant called the laryon.

[278.0s - 297.2s]: And that particular plant and its flowers then are fermented into a very potent fertility agent for us that we can use on a small as a backyard garden to its largest thousand acre farms.

[297.3s - 304.7s]: And the quality of that particular preparation that we make is to bring about warmth.

[306.0s - 312.4s]: So for instance it's really practical use is for someone who may be growing fruit trees.

[313.3s - 320.5s]: When we have laid frosts in the spring we can use this particular preparation to prevent them from having frost.

[321.5s - 331.7s]: Similarly if we want to extend our season so that we're growing earlier in the season or later in the season we can treat our seeds with laryon.

[332.5s - 344.8s]: And then that laryon can assist those seeds in understanding creating their own wisdom about how to be able to withstand a larger range of temperature.

[344.8s - 353.2s]: So it's a very very practical preparation and I love making it because it's a craft. It's like making fine wine.

[353.7s - 359.1s]: And there are several steps to it. And the first step is to harvest just the flowers.

[359.9s - 367.1s]: And then we put them in water. So this is just the laryon flower.

[368.1s - 373.9s]: And it's on a stem we would probably take the stem off eventually.

[374.7s - 379.3s]: And then we let it steep in water to get the flowers nice and juicy.

[380.1s - 384.0s]: After it's steeped in this water for a little while we grind it up.

[384.8s - 390.5s]: We can use anything to grind it up like a food mill or whatever.

[390.5s - 400.4s]: Then we press it. And when we press it it turns into this really gorgeous brown liquid.

[401.0s - 415.1s]: And this brown liquid if you had a smeller on this camera you'd understand that it smells like a very strangely fragrant wine after it's fermented.

[415.1s - 423.9s]: It reminds me of a little bit of some of those really beautiful, unique balsamic vinegars we can get from a particular place.

[423.9s - 427.7s]: Exactly. It is a very resembling a balsamic vinegare.

[428.3s - 431.0s]: Particularly when it's fermented for a long period of time.

[433.1s - 440.8s]: So where I keep all of my potions going to put in my root cellar I have various years of laryon.

[440.8s - 443.2s]: This is my favorite, this was 2013.

[444.5s - 446.2s]: And this is actually how it's made.

[446.5s - 455.1s]: So once the juice is pressed out it goes into one of these little fermenting chambers which has just a bit of water in here so that it can anaerobicly ferment.

[455.7s - 457.6s]: So this is last year's laryon.

[458.8s - 465.8s]: And so the rhythm in biodynamics is extremely important and it keeps us grounded on the earth.

[465.8s - 470.3s]: It keeps us grounded on the earth and its relationship to the cosmos.

[471.4s - 482.4s]: So in the summertime when things are out and blooming and growing there are many many many rhythms that have little pulsations in time.

[483.2s - 492.0s]: In the course of the year there are also many rhythms but they sometimes stretch out that of course we know as the seasons.

[493.0s - 505.9s]: But during the summertime certain plants that we're using for our fertility here in biodynamics are in bloom and it's the day to harvest them and that's what you do on that particular day.

[506.6s - 512.3s]: And it keeps you in touch, it keeps you grounded so that you understand your relationship to the cosmos.

[512.3s - 523.2s]: And it keeps you in a sense of relationship that keeps you mindful of what it is that we're doing here on earth.

[524.5s - 529.3s]: So that was just a little aside that I wanted to share with you, the laryon.

[530.1s - 537.7s]: One of the principles that's really important about dynamics is on farm fertility or in your garden fertility.

[537.7s - 548.9s]: In other words it's really not necessary for us to you know supply our gardens with things that come from a bag.

[549.4s - 559.3s]: We can actually make our own fertility in our gardens and make our own fertility within the organism that is our garden or our farm.

[559.3s - 569.0s]: And it's very simple to do and that's what I really love about teaching biodynamics is teaching that self-sufficiency that we can have as gardeners and farmers.

[569.7s - 582.9s]: You know one of the things that I know you and I have talked about a few times together that excites me almost beyond words is the potency and the empowerment that gives us as people.

[582.9s - 587.9s]: And this doesn't require us to go back to the land necessarily.

[588.6s - 595.7s]: It doesn't mean we have to every one of us become a farmer in our own perhaps suburban neighborhood.

[595.7s - 606.0s]: Even if we're in an urban setting and we have a shared community gardens down the street, there is so much we can be doing to empower ourselves with this fertility, with soil building.

[606.0s - 613.7s]: And I'm just struck that we have read it our fingertips and extraordinarily potent tool when it comes to the biodynamic work.

[614.3s - 624.2s]: And I know this is a big part of your teaching and the work you're doing, you're by your getting more and more folks engaged in that practice.

[624.2s - 635.1s]: And I think the other piece that's starting to be coined more and more and more about our work on the land is that we're regenerating.

[635.5s - 637.7s]: We're not just sustaining, we're regenerating.

[638.5s - 644.8s]: And there are many regenerative practices that whose aim is to build soil.

[645.5s - 647.0s]: The plants are secondary.

[647.8s - 650.7s]: The soil is really what we're doing and what we're working with.

[651.3s - 660.9s]: And that's why I really feel strongly about some of the new thought things that are coming out in regenerative agriculture around combining disciplines.

[662.5s - 672.9s]: So we've started to coin a term for the dynamics and have taught our first workshop in that particular discipline, just this spring in Virginia.

[672.9s - 680.4s]: And a lot of people are starting to understand that there's no dogma here about these disciplines.

[680.8s - 684.3s]: If they work and they marry together, we should be using them together.

[684.9s - 686.0s]: I love it every bunch of you.

[686.0s - 690.7s]: One of my favorite bumper stickers that says my karma ran over my dogma.

[691.0s - 697.8s]: And maybe some of our audience is familiar with permaculture and familiar with biodynamics.

[697.8s - 704.0s]: But I imagine some of our audience may not be familiar with those two terms, concepts and practices.

[704.0s - 710.6s]: And I'm wondering in a nutshell, how would you describe permaculture on the one hand and biodynamics on the other?

[710.8s - 716.4s]: You've already given us a flavor of what biodynamics is, but in a nutshell, how would you explain those two?

[717.1s - 726.4s]: Well, permaculture, to me permaculture is best described as something that man institutes on a particular piece of ground,

[726.4s - 733.1s]: be it a garden, be it a farm, whatever scale, such that we're mimicking nature.

[733.7s - 737.5s]: We're coming into a piece of ground and we're saying, what is here?

[737.9s - 739.3s]: What is crossing this land?

[739.9s - 742.9s]: Be it sun, wind, water, etc.

[743.6s - 745.4s]: That we can observe as human beings.

[745.9s - 752.4s]: And how is it that it's affecting what's going on in the soil and what's going on in the plants that are there already?

[753.4s - 762.2s]: Once we discover that kind of really deep observation on any piece of land, from a backyard garden to a rooftop garden,

[762.5s - 774.7s]: to thousands of acres of farmland, we then become way more educated stewards about how to manage that land in its best form.

[774.7s - 783.5s]: How can it manage itself in its best form with our guidance such that we're just lightly stewarding it?

[783.9s - 787.5s]: We're not imposing, we're just lightly stewarding it.

[787.7s - 788.8s]: There are many, many techniques.

[789.6s - 794.2s]: And I actually think that permaculture is best described in the flesh.

[794.8s - 800.6s]: So I think we'll probably go outside and start taking a few of those little demonstrations, start.

[801.6s - 802.1s]: That's beautiful.

[802.8s - 806.0s]: And before we go outside, I'm really excited to get out there.

[806.2s - 816.0s]: But before we go outside, what would the practice of biodynamics, how would you describe that concisely to a person who wasn't familiar with it?

[816.5s - 825.1s]: So biodynamics is really taking the practice of agriculture one step forward to re-spiritualizing the earth.

[825.1s - 839.8s]: And what we do in having that come forth in our stewardship practices is to understand that land can be viewed as an organism, just like we can.

[840.7s - 851.5s]: So land can be viewed as an organism that breathes, that digests, that has a will force, that moves, that changes, that is in livined.

[852.2s - 856.7s]: And we can create that in a vision for a piece of land.

[857.1s - 865.7s]: So a farm as an organism is one of the primary principles of biodynamics in creating that organism is our task.

[866.7s - 873.8s]: To do that, we understand also a more of a viewpoint of geosentrism.

[873.8s - 889.3s]: So that means that if you're a plant and you're growing on earth, you have a certain perspective growing on earth that's different than us humans who understand that the earth is orbiting the sun.

[889.3s - 911.6s]: From a plant's perspective, a plant understands the whole of its connection as it's growing on earth with the cosmos, with all of the planets, with the stars, with the Milky Way, and with all of the constellations that comprise our solar system.

[912.6s - 924.3s]: So that viewpoint is how we actually approach working with plants in biodynamics and allowing them to best express these cells.

[925.1s - 936.3s]: There are many, many ways that plants tell us that they're influenced by the cosmos, both in the way that they grow, in their rhythms, even in the face of their flowers.

[937.3s - 941.3s]: So that's another really strong tenet of biodynamics.

[941.9s - 961.4s]: The third one is that we utilize the plants in a certain way that expresses their archetype to make homeopathic medicines for the earth, and that is our fertility in biodynamics, along with just basic good organic practices.

[961.4s - 990.6s]: So these three principles really marry one another to create the environment where we bring spirit into agriculture, utilizing this organismic approach, utilizing the connection that we have with the rest of the cosmos, and understanding the archetypical energies of certain plants that we use as fertility.

[993.4s - 1007.9s]: Anthroposophy is the underlying spiritual form of biodynamics, and anthroposophy means anthropos, which is the man, anthroposophia, which is the wisdom.

[1008.2s - 1015.2s]: So the wisdom of man is anthroposophy, and that was coined by Rudolf Steiner back in 1924.

[1017.3s - 1032.1s]: It's not a complicated way of approaching agriculture. It's easy to learn. It makes you feel very self-sufficient and connected grounded.

[1033.6s - 1043.8s]: Thank you so much Pat. You know, one of the things that really strikes me, I don't think I mentioned in the introduction of you and your background that you are also a nurse practitioner.

[1043.8s - 1068.0s]: And you have a very solid Western medicine, scientific background, and more and more of my friends, colleagues, and mentors are helping me understand that a couple centuries ago we had this profound transition from an alchemical worldview to a chemical worldview, and perhaps something was lost along that transition.

[1068.0s - 1091.1s]: Certainly we've made many gains, and many arenas to be celebrated for sure at the same time. We've had a lot of negative consequences as well in this age of chemistry, and it strikes me that there's something going on with biodynamics that is helping us reconnect to a perhaps deeper or wiser understanding of what it means to be living on planet Earth.

[1091.1s - 1094.9s]: And it's just that in many respects we've lost in modern culture.

[1095.3s - 1112.5s]: We're seeking that connection. So the idea that a plant living on Earth has a body and has a wise person in that body is something that is attainable by all of us.

[1112.5s - 1132.7s]: It's easy for us to understand that when we connect with plants. And connecting with the idea that their wisdom can be accessed by us and can be promoted by us is another way of us connecting with everything that really is us.

[1132.7s - 1161.7s]: There is really no separation there. We're all the same. And so part of that is a principle called homiopathy, which is where you take a small essence of what may be something that the plant needs for its wisdom to develop, and you give that plant that space of wisdom to take in what it needs through the compost pile through the biodynamic preparations.

[1161.9s - 1174.4s]: To perform that it's very highest best self. Then when we eat that plant, we're performing at our very best highest self.

[1175.2s - 1183.5s]: So it's a connected way of looking at things instead of a mechanistic way of looking at there's something wrong that's corrected.

[1184.9s - 1188.8s]: It's more there's something wise, let's access it.

[1191.4s - 1197.7s]: Making notes as rapidly as I can with all of this. Well, this is so wonderful. What do you think should we head outside?

[1197.9s - 1198.2s]: Thank you.

[1198.4s - 1199.5s]: That sounds great.

[1200.6s - 1212.0s]: Okay, so just to orient you where we are here in the landscape. This is a permaculture gilded orchard that's about 16 years old.

[1213.0s - 1224.8s]: And what you'll notice here is if you pan this way and just look behind us, you'll notice that this does not look like any normal orchard.

[1225.5s - 1236.5s]: What you'll see in here is a very diverse mixture of plants that are living in kind of a tribal nature together that complement one another.

[1237.5s - 1250.4s]: So it consists of a canopy which is all of the fruit trees back here. And there are apples, peaches, cherries, both sour and sweet plums.

[1251.2s - 1260.8s]: And then there are also little bushberries over here which you can see that are nanking cherries that are actually grown mostly for the birds.

[1261.8s - 1273.0s]: There are several medicinal herbs in here. One is comfrey which is a dynamic, we call this a dynamic accumulator of nutrients.

[1273.9s - 1279.7s]: And we plant it everywhere in permaculture landscapes specifically to accumulate nutrients.

[1280.6s - 1295.0s]: Another one is this little plant which is alfalfa. Again a dynamic accumulator of nitrogen fixer which helps to build soil beneath what we're standing on.

[1296.8s - 1306.5s]: Further down in the orchard there are some other plants that are also nitrogen fixers, both shrubs as well as ground cover.

[1307.3s - 1318.2s]: What we're standing in right here is what's called a swale. This is how we capture and store water which is one of the principles of permaculture.

[1319.1s - 1328.1s]: Capturing and storing energy in the form of water is extremely important in this particular landscape because we only get 13 inches of grain a year.

[1329.1s - 1342.0s]: So one way of capturing water is to make just a simple ditch instead of a straight ditch where most people here in the western slope irrigate their fruit trees.

[1342.3s - 1357.1s]: This ditch actually follows the contour of the land and therefore the water moves very slowly and sinks very deeply and nourishes these fruit trees and all of the foods that are on the floor all at once.

[1357.1s - 1386.3s]: So this acts like a huge lens underground capturing and storing water and nutrients for the trees. Further down in the orchard there is a whole bank of nitrogen fixing shrubs and the way that those release nitrogen is to just be chopped off in the spring time then their nodules on their root feed into the soil and release nitrogen for the fruit trees.

[1386.3s - 1407.0s]: So this is just a very graphic example of how permaculture works to build soil. It works by not disturbing the soil as much as possible and by keeping things permanent and as much as permanent as possible so as many perennials as possible.

[1407.0s - 1417.8s]: And when we move down into the cultivation beds you'll see some permanent culture that is food that keeps coming up here after year.

[1418.8s - 1429.5s]: One of the things I love about a system like this Pat is it really makes explicit the super abundance of the conditions on earth.

[1429.5s - 1445.8s]: For example there is a whole lot of nitrogen in the atmosphere. Right it's a very abundant element in our atmosphere and to have plants right here in this place pulling it down and getting it into the soil you don't need to bring in an artificial nitrogen based fertilizer.

[1445.8s - 1468.7s]: Right which is of course a multi-billion dollar industry and you know we've made certain decisions over the course of the last several decades for a variety of reasons but we have an opportunity to return our agriculture back to something that's in closer rhythm with nature cycles and is taking you could say better advantage of the natural abundance of this place.

[1468.7s - 1484.8s]: Right and you can imagine how much carbon is being sequestered here. We never we never turn this over. We might graze it just so that it would regenerate a little bit but that's about the only turnover that happens here.

[1485.4s - 1493.7s]: Might mow it down a little bit. The mostly I spend time in my hammock watching it grow. I love it.

[1493.7s - 1502.8s]: Okay we'll walk through the orchard this way. Okay. Take you on a little tour by the camera and end up in the most annual bed. Excellent.

[1514.6s - 1519.9s]: Feel free to snack on the hatcheries. Most of them are getting pretty light.

[1523.7s - 1528.5s]: Give a quick shout out to my son Hunter who's manning the camera today. Hi everybody.

[1535.3s - 1536.3s]: Oh delicious.

[1565.0s - 1573.0s]: So here we have an example of the diversity of cultivation field.

[1574.4s - 1592.6s]: What we're standing on here is a cover crop of rye which was about this tall about a week ago and we mowed it off and we just are leaving it like this to decompose a little bit into the soil.

[1593.6s - 1605.3s]: After it decomposes a little bit we'll rough up the soil just a teeny bit and then we'll grow another cover crop in it and then this soil will be prepared for food next year.

[1606.5s - 1622.4s]: Other than that it really doesn't get any other treatment. So instead of having us planted fence post to fence post we strategically improve certain strips of soil in this field so that they're

[1622.4s - 1627.2s]: primed for food production and we get the very best food production we can.

[1628.6s - 1639.3s]: We also have a really diverse strip in here of different perennials that provide several different things.

[1640.1s - 1647.9s]: Number one they provide medicinal herbs. This is St. John's Ward here almost coming into bloom.

[1647.9s - 1658.1s]: This is the Valerian we spoke about further over here is Yaro which is a very diverse medicinal herb.

[1658.3s - 1659.7s]: There's a bunch down in here too.

[1660.2s - 1666.8s]: And they're all growing together and you'll notice that there aren't any spaces on the soil.

[1666.8s - 1673.1s]: We want to keep the soil covered like a blanket. You know to keep it to keep it protected.

[1673.8s - 1686.8s]: And if you continually agitate soil with tillers and machines and things like that then it never has a chance to make the glue that pulls everything together that nourishes the roots of the plants.

[1687.4s - 1690.3s]: So you keep everything covered as much as possible.

[1691.6s - 1707.6s]: In this particular bed you will walk through and find butterflies, ladybugs, parasitic wasps, honey bees, fragrant flowers, things that you can enjoy all the time.

[1707.6s - 1721.4s]: The other thing that's growing in here that's a little known benefit is this is a perennial nitrogen fixing the gune called sand flange.

[1721.7s - 1727.0s]: It's an amazing forage for animals because it doesn't cause blood.

[1727.4s - 1730.5s]: And it's also a very valuable seed crop.

[1731.5s - 1739.4s]: So in this particular bed I have two of the eight biodynamic herbs that I need to make fertility.

[1740.5s - 1743.7s]: I have a seed crop that provides me with an income.

[1744.4s - 1748.3s]: I have other medicinal herbs that provide me with medicine.

[1749.1s - 1754.6s]: There are fruit trees growing in amongst all of these that provide me with fruit.

[1754.6s - 1760.0s]: In the ground cover further up this bed we have strawberries and lusards.

[1760.8s - 1772.9s]: So most everything that's growing here is either edible, has a medicinal value or has a nutritional value for animals and the soil and us.

[1773.4s - 1774.7s]: Absolutely beautiful.

[1775.3s - 1781.6s]: And so even though it looks very wild we want it to look wild.

[1782.0s - 1782.7s]: This is nature.

[1783.2s - 1791.7s]: This is nature reconstructed in a permaculture-esque manner so that we want it to stay wild like this.

[1791.9s - 1794.9s]: We don't want it to be disturbed all the time.

[1796.5s - 1797.8s]: Now come with me.

[1814.9s - 1824.7s]: Now this side of the production bed is where we actually are growing food for production this year.

[1825.6s - 1828.2s]: Again you don't see any bare ground.

[1828.8s - 1830.8s]: I don't mind that the weeds are here.

[1831.1s - 1832.5s]: They don't take up too much nutrients.

[1833.0s - 1836.6s]: In fact they actually mine up nutrients for the plants.

[1837.5s - 1840.6s]: In the midst of it you see this long long hedgerow.

[1841.2s - 1851.1s]: This long hedgerow has all berries, cherries, currents, raspberries, all kinds of things in here for us to eat.

[1851.1s - 1854.1s]: And so it also pulls in diversity.

[1854.6s - 1860.0s]: It pulls in birds, it pulls in insects, it acts as a waterlands, captures water.

[1860.5s - 1865.7s]: All through in here this is cover crop that will also then be turned over.

[1866.5s - 1873.4s]: Have potatoes, peas, garlic, onions, greens, etc. etc. and then another hedgerow.

[1874.4s - 1884.0s]: So these hedgerow are really important in permaculture because they do something in the landscape to create a block for the wind.

[1884.7s - 1886.0s]: Which we can feel right now.

[1887.0s - 1897.3s]: And these hedgerow have diversity in them as well as the windbreak that allows the landscape to settle a little bit.

[1898.3s - 1902.1s]: Instead of being hushed across it, it's settles.

[1902.8s - 1912.3s]: It's just a little bit gentler, sweeter, nicer than it would be if this were just the meadow that it was when we first came in here.

[1913.9s - 1923.2s]: And then right below your feet where you're standing, this is a trial in here that I'm doing for Rocky Mountain Sea Alliance.

[1924.2s - 1933.8s]: Where I'm growing several different kinds of heritage wheat, sorghum, corn, sunflower, beans, all to see how well they do here.

[1935.0s - 1948.1s]: So that if they do well, then we know that this will be a good thing to breed seeds that are adapted to this particular climate.

[1948.7s - 1955.2s]: And the only treatment that this field receives is the bottom limit for fertility.

[1956.7s - 1966.2s]: There's a theme running through all of this of the local knowledge and relationships that emerge even in the plants themselves.

[1966.7s - 1974.2s]: It's not a one size fits all kind of solution across an entire state or continent or even region.

[2563.0s - 2574.9s]: If I check out here in a little while, it's okay because I've done right with her. I've done right with her. I've done all I can to take care of her.

[2574.9s - 2596.2s]: And I think keeping that still small voice in the back of our heads of not doing harm can just possibly turn us over to the next evolutionary step that we have here on the planet to regenerate the planet.

[2600.3s - 2604.2s]: Hopefully somebody will come and visit us here. She's being pretty shy.

[2605.1s - 2618.4s]: So this is Diamond. Diamond is the large, very lumbering, very gentle, wise presence of fertility here on the farm.

[2619.4s - 2629.6s]: This is my dairy cow. She's about three and a half, almost four years old now. And lingering over in the shadows and hopefully she'll come over and visit us.

[2630.0s - 2635.8s]: This is her brand new Heppacap of about three weeks now. Let's sweep these.

[2637.0s - 2647.2s]: And these guys run the fertility out of time. She provides us with the highest quality protein we have on the farm.

[2648.2s - 2655.1s]: Milk, cheese, butter, ice cream, sour cream, all kinds of different kinds of cheeses.

[2656.6s - 2665.6s]: Depending on what sex of calf she has, if she has male calves, we slaughter those at about two years for meat.

[2667.3s - 2685.1s]: In the meantime, we get all of her great fertility here. One of the real important aspects of biodynamics and permaculture is making sure that the fertility on the farm matches the scale of the farm.

[2685.1s - 2693.3s]: So like if you're in the city and you have a backyard garden, the fertility that you can create there might be a chicken or a duck.

[2695.2s - 2713.6s]: And that might be the exact scale that you need. Here on this farm, we have six acres of pasture that really does pretty much do about the right scale of supply and demand for one calf.

[2714.6s - 2720.2s]: We could potentially have two as many as three, but not much more than that.

[2720.6s - 2730.8s]: And so that means that all the grass that's growing here is what she needs for her life for almost the entire year.

[2731.4s - 2741.6s]: So we rotate her back and forth on these pastures so that we can ham sometimes and we can keep the grass back so that she has fresh pasture all year.

[2741.6s - 2747.7s]: So that we mean the calf to the pasture when we finally get to a really heavy milking cycle.

[2749.8s - 2758.3s]: And then her fertility in the form of manure goes into the compost pile and recirculates on back onto the farm.

[2759.5s - 2770.5s]: You know some of our audience may not really be as familiar with this notion of regenerative agriculture and what this means in terms of ruminant manure going into the soil building process.

[2770.7s - 2772.9s]: And perhaps you could describe that for folks.

[2773.4s - 2778.3s]: So the ruminant manure is a very different kind of manure because it goes through four stomachs.

[2778.3s - 2793.6s]: And as it goes through four stomachs, the cow regurgitates the manure in the form of cudd in that first digestion, second digestion, third and fourth digestion are what finally culminates in cow manure.

[2794.1s - 2805.1s]: Each time that that cudd is generated into a new stomach, all of the stomachs of a cow are made up of the shapes of nature.

[2805.1s - 2825.3s]: So one cow stomach is a waterfall, another cow stomach is a honeycomb, another cow stomach is kind of a fur, a pillard interior that's kind of like the interior of our gastrointestinal tract with lots of little pili.

[2826.3s - 2839.7s]: And those shapes in nature are replicated, replicated, touching all of that plant material and that plant material and the interior of the cow stomach are communicating intelligence back and forth.

[2840.4s - 2846.2s]: All the while when the cow is ruminating, that's what we call it, that's why we call it ruminating.

[2846.2s - 2858.8s]: They're actually meditating when they're out on pasture and a form of that meditation has to do with the fact that most biodynamic cows keep their horns.

[2859.7s - 2866.0s]: Their horns actually are a really important organ for them to be able to communicate with the earth.

[2866.8s - 2875.8s]: And so to take a cow's horn off, dulls the animal, but we keep them on because we want them to have that intelligence.

[2876.5s - 2890.6s]: So that ruminating process with the manure and as it comes back on the ground signals when it comes back on the ground a certain rhythm within that manure, spring manure is different than winter manure.

[2891.6s - 2896.8s]: It has a different quality because in winter we don't have all of this, we have hay.

[2897.9s - 2907.5s]: And so the quality of manure of a ruminant animal is something that's wholly different than an animal who has one stomach or two stomachs.

[2908.1s - 2915.9s]: And that's why we use the cow. They're very meditative. They're like an organ of digestion on legs, really.

[2915.9s - 2925.7s]: That's really what they are. They're just gigantic organs of digestion moving through the landscape and meditating landscape as they eat it.

[2925.8s - 2935.2s]: In the meantime, they produce this amazing, besides the manure, this amazing quality of milk.

[2935.2s - 2940.1s]: Milk is one of the best fertilizers that you can put on the ground.

[2940.8s - 2953.2s]: In fact, when I stir by dynamic preparations, I often stir them in milk, her milk, so that that intelligence that's coming onto the land can come in very different forms, milk being one.

[2954.2s - 2966.3s]: It's also alive. You don't homogenize or pasteurize the milk. We eat it raw. We make all the yogurts and cheeses and butter and everything out of it raw.

[2966.8s - 2981.9s]: The only thing that we do with the milk to heat it or change it in anyway is when we make yogurt, we displace the normal bacteria in the milk and replace it with new bacteria that we specifically culture to make yogurt.

[2983.6s - 2990.7s]: Fresh cheeses are one of the... We eat like kings. We work a lot, but we eat like kings.

[2993.3s - 3008.0s]: There's this theme running through all of us, too, of the microbiome doing its work in the cow's stomachs, in the soil, the living critters, in the live milk, the culture of the milk.

[3008.0s - 3013.9s]: It gives a whole deeper meaning to this notion of a land of milk and honey, doesn't it?

[3014.7s - 3018.0s]: There's actually a milk and honey bio-dynamic spray, too, that we use.

[3018.9s - 3036.9s]: In an all-flows together, not too long ago, there was an article about a decade now, as well as in Stone Nurse, about the hygiene principle, being something that was starting to be examinous.

[3036.9s - 3046.4s]: Maybe it's not so great for our kids. Maybe it's not so great for everything to be so cleansed up with bleach and detergent and sterilized.

[3046.8s - 3064.0s]: Maybe it would be such a great idea for them to just kind of eat a little dirt on a farm every now and then to create the conditions of diversity inside of our gut biomes, and that perhaps that would help their immune systems get educated.

[3064.0s - 3080.9s]: That was published 10 years ago, and now it's clearly been documented over and over and over again, the dangers of sterilizing our gut from antibiotic use in animals that were eating.

[3081.3s - 3085.8s]: So here, that just doesn't apply at all.

[3087.2s - 3088.1s]: Beautiful.

[3092.0s - 3094.1s]: Sweet Peas got a little slice of heaven here.

segments.text: Welcome to the Writers' Community's Stewardship and Sustainability Podcast Series.
Today we have the opportunity to visit with Farmer and Expert Educator Pat Frazier.
Hi Pat.
Hi.
It's great to visit with you.
Yeah.
Good that you made it over.
We did.
We had a beautiful drive through the mountains to get here.
Sweet.
Pat Frazier has been a biodynamic farmer for over 20 years.
She and her family have a small biodynamic homestead diversified farm and family dairy
in western Colorado where all of the preparation herbs are grown and utilized in making the indigenous
biodynamic preparations for her farm organism and western Colorado regional biodynamic
group.
Permaculture design is another of her passions and its marriage with biodynamics is included
in her two-week residential permaculture certification in the summers.
Pat is a passionate cultivator of the biodynamic agriculture movement speaking nationally and
regionally at major biodynamic conferences and advising on three national organizations.
She is the president of the Board of Directors of Josephine Porter Institute for Applied
Biodynamics, the largest nonprofit distributor of biodynamic preparations in North America.
And Pat, I have been looking forward to this conversation for quite a while now and I'm
so thrilled we have the opportunity to share with our audience a direct conversation with
you about biodynamics and permaculture and all of this amazing work we can be doing
more of in our lives and in our homes regardless of our particular setting.
So thanks for taking the time to visit with us.
You're welcome.
You're welcome.
So we have a lot to talk about.
What do you feel like would be a nice place to start?
I think today the best place to start is one of the real main principles of either permaculture
or biodynamics which is rhythm.
So as you know we just passed the Fourth of July.
Today is July 6th and we had a very auspicious day on the 3rd of July which was a day where
the calendar indicated that in the cosmos there was an opposition happening.
An opposition is where the moon is here, the earth is here and on the other side is a planet.
And so the moon actually emphasizes and really brings forth all of the qualities and whatever
planet is over here on the other side of the earth.
And on July 3rd that happened to be moon opposed Saturn.
Now Saturn when Rudolph Steiner spoke to us about biodynamics at that time Saturn was the furthest planet out.
And so it was the planet where all evolution began with regards to what we now know as the earth evolution.
And when it began evolving the only quality that Saturn had was warmth.
It was the quality of warmth that generated all life.
In biodynamics we have an association with certain plants on earth with certain planets.
And those associations are what create some of the herbs and the fermented preparations that we use for fertility in biodynamics.
In July usually at about this time in July one of the plants that associated with Saturn is in full bloom.
And so on July 3rd not only was that plant in full bloom but that plant's associated planet Saturn was emphasized by the moon.
So what we did on that day was a very rhythmic exercise where we harvested just the flowers of the plant called the laryon.
And that particular plant and its flowers then are fermented into a very potent fertility agent for us that we can use on a small as a backyard garden to its largest thousand acre farms.
And the quality of that particular preparation that we make is to bring about warmth.
So for instance it's really practical use is for someone who may be growing fruit trees.
When we have laid frosts in the spring we can use this particular preparation to prevent them from having frost.
Similarly if we want to extend our season so that we're growing earlier in the season or later in the season we can treat our seeds with laryon.
And then that laryon can assist those seeds in understanding creating their own wisdom about how to be able to withstand a larger range of temperature.
So it's a very very practical preparation and I love making it because it's a craft. It's like making fine wine.
And there are several steps to it. And the first step is to harvest just the flowers.
And then we put them in water. So this is just the laryon flower.
And it's on a stem we would probably take the stem off eventually.
And then we let it steep in water to get the flowers nice and juicy.
After it's steeped in this water for a little while we grind it up.
We can use anything to grind it up like a food mill or whatever.
Then we press it. And when we press it it turns into this really gorgeous brown liquid.
And this brown liquid if you had a smeller on this camera you'd understand that it smells like a very strangely fragrant wine after it's fermented.
It reminds me of a little bit of some of those really beautiful, unique balsamic vinegars we can get from a particular place.
Exactly. It is a very resembling a balsamic vinegare.
Particularly when it's fermented for a long period of time.
So where I keep all of my potions going to put in my root cellar I have various years of laryon.
This is my favorite, this was 2013.
And this is actually how it's made.
So once the juice is pressed out it goes into one of these little fermenting chambers which has just a bit of water in here so that it can anaerobicly ferment.
So this is last year's laryon.
And so the rhythm in biodynamics is extremely important and it keeps us grounded on the earth.
It keeps us grounded on the earth and its relationship to the cosmos.
So in the summertime when things are out and blooming and growing there are many many many rhythms that have little pulsations in time.
In the course of the year there are also many rhythms but they sometimes stretch out that of course we know as the seasons.
But during the summertime certain plants that we're using for our fertility here in biodynamics are in bloom and it's the day to harvest them and that's what you do on that particular day.
And it keeps you in touch, it keeps you grounded so that you understand your relationship to the cosmos.
And it keeps you in a sense of relationship that keeps you mindful of what it is that we're doing here on earth.
So that was just a little aside that I wanted to share with you, the laryon.
One of the principles that's really important about dynamics is on farm fertility or in your garden fertility.
In other words it's really not necessary for us to you know supply our gardens with things that come from a bag.
We can actually make our own fertility in our gardens and make our own fertility within the organism that is our garden or our farm.
And it's very simple to do and that's what I really love about teaching biodynamics is teaching that self-sufficiency that we can have as gardeners and farmers.
You know one of the things that I know you and I have talked about a few times together that excites me almost beyond words is the potency and the empowerment that gives us as people.
And this doesn't require us to go back to the land necessarily.
It doesn't mean we have to every one of us become a farmer in our own perhaps suburban neighborhood.
Even if we're in an urban setting and we have a shared community gardens down the street, there is so much we can be doing to empower ourselves with this fertility, with soil building.
And I'm just struck that we have read it our fingertips and extraordinarily potent tool when it comes to the biodynamic work.
And I know this is a big part of your teaching and the work you're doing, you're by your getting more and more folks engaged in that practice.
And I think the other piece that's starting to be coined more and more and more about our work on the land is that we're regenerating.
We're not just sustaining, we're regenerating.
And there are many regenerative practices that whose aim is to build soil.
The plants are secondary.
The soil is really what we're doing and what we're working with.
And that's why I really feel strongly about some of the new thought things that are coming out in regenerative agriculture around combining disciplines.
So we've started to coin a term for the dynamics and have taught our first workshop in that particular discipline, just this spring in Virginia.
And a lot of people are starting to understand that there's no dogma here about these disciplines.
If they work and they marry together, we should be using them together.
I love it every bunch of you.
One of my favorite bumper stickers that says my karma ran over my dogma.
And maybe some of our audience is familiar with permaculture and familiar with biodynamics.
But I imagine some of our audience may not be familiar with those two terms, concepts and practices.
And I'm wondering in a nutshell, how would you describe permaculture on the one hand and biodynamics on the other?
You've already given us a flavor of what biodynamics is, but in a nutshell, how would you explain those two?
Well, permaculture, to me permaculture is best described as something that man institutes on a particular piece of ground,
be it a garden, be it a farm, whatever scale, such that we're mimicking nature.
We're coming into a piece of ground and we're saying, what is here?
What is crossing this land?
Be it sun, wind, water, etc.
That we can observe as human beings.
And how is it that it's affecting what's going on in the soil and what's going on in the plants that are there already?
Once we discover that kind of really deep observation on any piece of land, from a backyard garden to a rooftop garden,
to thousands of acres of farmland, we then become way more educated stewards about how to manage that land in its best form.
How can it manage itself in its best form with our guidance such that we're just lightly stewarding it?
We're not imposing, we're just lightly stewarding it.
There are many, many techniques.
And I actually think that permaculture is best described in the flesh.
So I think we'll probably go outside and start taking a few of those little demonstrations, start.
That's beautiful.
And before we go outside, I'm really excited to get out there.
But before we go outside, what would the practice of biodynamics, how would you describe that concisely to a person who wasn't familiar with it?
So biodynamics is really taking the practice of agriculture one step forward to re-spiritualizing the earth.
And what we do in having that come forth in our stewardship practices is to understand that land can be viewed as an organism, just like we can.
So land can be viewed as an organism that breathes, that digests, that has a will force, that moves, that changes, that is in livined.
And we can create that in a vision for a piece of land.
So a farm as an organism is one of the primary principles of biodynamics in creating that organism is our task.
To do that, we understand also a more of a viewpoint of geosentrism.
So that means that if you're a plant and you're growing on earth, you have a certain perspective growing on earth that's different than us humans who understand that the earth is orbiting the sun.

From a plant's perspective, a plant understands the whole of its connection as it's growing on earth with the cosmos, with all of the planets, with the stars, with the Milky Way, and with all of the constellations that comprise our solar system.
So that viewpoint is how we actually approach working with plants in biodynamics and allowing them to best express these cells.
There are many, many ways that plants tell us that they're influenced by the cosmos, both in the way that they grow, in their rhythms, even in the face of their flowers.
So that's another really strong tenet of biodynamics.

The third one is that we utilize the plants in a certain way that expresses their archetype to make homeopathic medicines for the earth, and that is our fertility in biodynamics, along with just basic good organic practices.

So these three principles really marry one another to create the environment where we bring spirit into agriculture, utilizing this organismic approach, utilizing the connection that we have with the rest of the cosmos, and understanding the archetypical energies of certain plants that we use as fertility.
Anthroposophy is the underlying spiritual form of biodynamics, and anthroposophy means anthropos, which is the man, anthroposophia, which is the wisdom.
